Analysis: Analyze the distribution of admission rates to understand the competitiveness of colleges.
Examine the correlation between SAT/ACT scores and other features like tuition and completion rates.
Identify the most common predominant degrees and highest degrees offered by colleges.
Explore the relationship between geographical location (region) and college characteristics.
Investigate the impact of ownership (public, private nonprofit) on college metrics like tuition and faculty salary.
Handle missing values by imputing them based on the mean or median of the feature, or using more advanced techniques like KNN imputation.
Normalize or standardize numerical features to ensure they have a similar scale.
Encode categorical variables using techniques like one-hot encoding or label encoding.
Remove outliers in features like tuition and faculty salary to prevent skewing the model.
Create a validation set to assess model performance on unseen data.
Create a feature representing the overall diversity of the student body by combining percent_white, percent_black, percent_hispanic, and percent_asian.
Generate a feature that captures the affordability ratio by dividing average_cost_academic_year by tuition_(instate).
Derive a feature indicating the faculty-to-student ratio to understand the teaching environment.
Develop a feature that combines SAT/ACT scores to represent the overall academic rigor required for admission.
Construct a feature that measures the earnings potential by comparing mean_earnings_6_years and mean_earnings_10_years.
Experiment with different models like Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Neural Networks to see which performs best.
Use cross-validation to ensure the model's robustness and generalization capability.
Implement early stopping during training to prevent overfitting.
Tune hyperparameters using grid search or random search to optimize model performance.
Incorporate feature importance analysis to understand which features contribute most to the model's predictions and potentially refine the feature set.
